system_message:
You are simulating a realistic inpatient doctor–patient conversation for a single hospital admission.
You MUST follow these rules:

1) Use only the facts provided in the EHR packet. Do NOT invent diagnoses, symptoms, test results, medications, procedures, timelines, or outcomes.
2) Every clinically factual statement MUST be supported by an explicit evidence citation using the provided EIDs (e.g., "Evidence: [LAB#000123, RAD#000004]").
3) If the EHR packet does not contain a fact, say you do not know or that it is not documented.
4) Produce a chronological conversation spanning the full admission, from admission through discharge.
5) Use RELATIVE time only (e.g., "H+03:15", "HospitalDay2 09:40"). Do not mention calendar dates or years.
6) Discharge summaries are provided; treat them as post-hoc summaries that help you maintain coherence, but do not reveal discharge outcomes before they occur in the chronology.
7) Output must be valid JSON, conforming exactly to the output schema described in the user message. No extra keys.

There were no pleural effusions and only mild chronic airway wall thickening.","supporting_eids":["RAD#000001","DS#000001"],"test":"CT chest without contrast"},{"relative_time":"HospitalDay2 17:10","result":"Noncontrast CT head demonstrated no evidence of acute infarct, hemorrhage, edema, mass, or mass effect. There were dense calcifications along the falx and cerebellar tentorium and basal ganglia, likely related to underlying ESRD. Overall, no acute intracranial process was identified.","supporting_eids":["RAD#000002","DS#000001"],"test":"CT head without contrast"},{"relative_time":"HospitalDay3 11:40","result":"Fluoroscopic-guided LP at L3–4 obtained 18 mL of clear CSF. CSF studies showed WBC 2/µL, RBC 0/µL, 0% neutrophils, 84% lymphocytes, 16% monocytes, protein 30 mg/dL, glucose 43 mg/dL, LDH 12 IU/L. Cryptococcal antigen was negative, Gram stain showed no organisms, and bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures showed no growth. Overall, there was no evidence of meningitis or other CNS infection.","supporting_eids":["RAD#000003","LAB#000105","LAB#000106","LAB#000107","LAB#000108","LAB#000109","LAB#000110","LAB#000111","LAB#000112","MICRO#000015","MICRO#000016","MICRO#000017","MICRO#000019","MICRO#000020","MICRO#000021","DS#000001"],"test":"Fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture and CSF analysis"},{"relative_time":"HospitalDay5 20:10","result":"Non-contrast MRI of the brain showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, or abnormal FLAIR signal to suggest a parenchymal process. There was mild pachymeningeal thickening likely post-procedural and mild sinus and mastoid mucosal thickening, but no intracranial pathology explaining the headaches.","supporting_eids":["RAD#000004","DS#000001"],"test":"MRI brain without contrast"},{"relative_time":"H-74:00 to HospitalDay3","result":"Punch biopsies from the left arm and right face showed ulcer and neutrophilic scale crust with dyskeratosis and superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophilia, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction status post excoriation, with follicular accentuation on the facial specimen. HSV and VZV immunostains were negative, and PAS-D and Gram stains did not reveal microorganisms. Tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staphylococcus. Findings were interpreted as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis, likely drug-related, rather than zoster.","supporting_eids":["PX#000001","MICRO#000009","MICRO#000010","MICRO#000011","MICRO#000012","MICRO#000013","MICRO#000014","DS#000001"],"test":"Skin biopsies of left arm and right face"},{"relative_time":"HospitalDay2–6","result":"Over the course of admission, serial labs showed persistent macrocytosis (MCV 103–105 fL), leukopenia (WBC 2.5–3.6 K/uL), thrombocytopenia (platelets 102–130 K/uL), and hemoglobin 10.1–12.2 g/dL. Renal indices fluctuated with dialysis, with pre-dialysis creatinine up to 9.2 mg/dL and BUN 72 mg/dL, improving post-dialysis to creatinine ~5.8–5.9 mg/dL and BUN 17–40 mg/dL; potassium ranged from 4.3 to 7.1 mEq/L, with highest values treated with kayexalate and dialysis. Phosphate remained mildly to moderately elevated.","supporting_eids":["LAB#000036","LAB#000037","LAB#000040","LAB#000041","LAB#000044","LAB#000045","LAB#000048","LAB#000051","LAB#000053","LAB#000055","LAB#000063","LAB#000065","LAB#000067","LAB#000068","LAB#000069","LAB#000072","LAB#000073","LAB#000076","LAB#000077","LAB#000081","LAB#000084","LAB#000085","LAB#000087","LAB#000088","LAB#000089","LAB#000091","LAB#000093","LAB#000095","LAB#000113","LAB#000114","LAB#000117","LAB#000118","LAB#000121","LAB#000122","LAB#000123","LAB#000126","LAB#000129","LAB#000130","LAB#000132","LAB#000133","LAB#000134","LAB#000137","LAB#000138","LAB#000141","LAB#000142","LAB#000143","LAB#000145","LAB#000147","LAB#000149","LAB#000150","LAB#000151","LAB#000153","LAB#000155","LAB#000157","LAB#000158","LAB#000159","LAB#000162","LAB#000163","LAB#000166","LAB#000167","LAB#000168","LAB#000171","LAB#000174","LAB#000175","LAB#000177","DS#000001"],"test":"Serial chemistry and hematology during hospitalization"}],"one_paragraph_summary":"During this admission, a middle-aged woman with advanced AIDS on HAART, ESRD on thrice-weekly hemodialysis, prior V1 zoster with post-herpetic neuralgia, atrial fibrillation, and chronic pruritic rash presented from dialysis with worsening right-sided headache and facial pain, new right facial blistering lesions, diffuse pruritus, dizziness, and mild shortness of breath. Initial evaluation showed chronic macrocytic anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, ESRD-range creatinine and BUN with hyperphosphatemia and intermittent hyperkalemia, but stable baseline low blood pressure and no fever. CT chest showed no PCP and only a small nonspecific right lower lobe ground-glass opacity; CT head and later MRI brain were normal. Dermatology performed punch biopsies of the left arm and right face, which demonstrated eosinophilic hypersensitivity/folliculitis with negative HSV/VZV stains and only coagulase-negative staph on culture, leading to discontinuation of acyclovir and treatment with hydroxyzine and topical mupirocin. A fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture yielded normal CSF with negative cryptococcal antigen and cultures, ruling out CNS infection as a cause of headache. She continued M/W/F hemodialysis with transient intradialytic hypotension and improved post-dialysis chemistries; sevelamer was increased and cinacalcet continued. Her HAART regimen (abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, emtricitabine) and opportunistic infection prophylaxis (TMP-SMX and azithromycin) were maintained. Atrial fibrillation remained paroxysmal and was managed with aspirin alone. By discharge she was hemodynamically stable at baseline, ambulatory, with improved facial lesions, pruritus, and headache, and was discharged home with services, on her chronic dialysis schedule and updated medications, with follow-up arranged for HIV care and suture removal.","problem_list":[{"problem":"Right facial rash and pain in the setting of prior V1 zoster","status_at_discharge":"Presented with worsening right facial pain and new ulcerative lesions on the right cheek and nasolabial fold, on a background of prior V1 zoster with post-herpetic neuralgia and right eye visual loss. Initial concern was for zoster reactivation, and she received systemic and topical acyclovir. Dermatology biopsies of the left arm and right face showed ulcer with neutrophilic crust and superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophils, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction/eosinophilic dermatitis with follicular accentuation; HSV and VZV immunostains were negative, and tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staphylococcus. DFA and viral cultures from skin scrapings were negative for HSV and VZV. Acyclovir was discontinued after ID and Dermatology review, and she was treated with hydroxyzine for pruritus and mupirocin cream twice daily to the facial lesions. By discharge, the facial ulcerations and pustules were greatly improved, with residual but decreased pain.","supporting_eids":["DX#000003","DX#000008","DX#000005","DS#000001","PX#000001","MICRO#000001","MICRO#000002","MICRO#000003","MICRO#000004","MICRO#000005","MICRO#000006","MICRO#000007","MICRO#000008","MICRO#000009","MICRO#000010","MICRO#000011","MICRO#000012","MICRO#000013","MICRO#000014","PHARM#000003","PHARM#000004","PHARM#000005","PHARM#000026","PHARM#000016","PHARM#000036","RX#000004","RX#000005","RX#000032","RX#000042"]},{"problem":"Headache with photophobia in advanced HIV","status_at_discharge":"She had chronic headaches that had increased in frequency and severity over several weeks, sometimes associated with photophobia but without nausea, vomiting, or neck stiffness. CT head and non-contrast MRI brain showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, or abnormal parenchymal signal. A fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture yielded clear CSF with 2 WBC/µL, normal protein and glucose, negative cryptococcal antigen, and negative bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures, effectively ruling out CNS infection. Headaches were managed symptomatically with oxycodone and later acetaminophen–caffeine–butalbital, with moderate improvement. At discharge she continued to have chronic headaches but at a reduced intensity, with plans for outpatient management.","supporting_eids":["DX#000007","RAD#000002","RAD#000003","RAD#000004","LAB#000105","LAB#000106","LAB#000107","LAB#000108","LAB#000109","LAB#000110","LAB#000111","LAB#000112","MICRO#000015","MICRO#000016","MICRO#000017","MICRO#000019","MICRO#000020","MICRO#000021","PHARM#000035","PHARM#000049","RX#000037","RX#000053","DS#000001"]},{"problem":"Eosinophilic folliculitis / eosinophilic dermatitis with diffuse pruritic rash","status_at_discharge":"She had a chronic, intensely pruritic rash with hyperpigmented papules and excoriations on the extremities and trunk, with peripheral eosinophilia on admission. Skin biopsies from the left arm and right face showed ulcer and neutrophilic scale crust with superficial perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate and eosinophils, consistent with hypersensitivity reaction with follicular accentuation, and special stains were negative for HSV, VZV, fungi, and bacteria. This was interpreted as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis, likely related to HIV and possibly drug reaction. She was treated with hydroxyzine for pruritus and topical mupirocin to areas of ulceration; her chronic prurigo lesions were healing by discharge, and itching was significantly improved.","supporting_eids":["DX#000005","DX#000008","LAB#000002","PX#000001","MICRO#000009","MICRO#000010","MICRO#000011","MICRO#000012","MICRO#000013","MICRO#000014","DS#000001","PHARM#000016","PHARM#000036","RX#000016","RX#000042"]},{"problem":"End-stage renal disease on hemodialysis with electrolyte abnormalities","status_at_discharge":"She has ESRD from HIV nephropathy and is anuric on chronic hemodialysis. During this admission she continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis (M/W/F). Pre-dialysis labs showed elevated creatinine (up to ~9.2 mg/dL), BUN (up to 72 mg/dL), hyperphosphatemia, and intermittent hyperkalemia (potassium up to 7.1 mEq/L), which improved post-dialysis (creatinine ~5.8–5.9 mg/dL, BUN in the 17–40 mg/dL range, potassium in the mid-4s). She experienced transient intradialytic hypotension that responded to small saline boluses. Her sevelamer dose was increased, and cinacalcet was continued; she also received doxercalciferol and epoetin with dialysis. At discharge she remained dialysis-dependent but hemodynamically stable, with plans to continue her outpatient dialysis schedule and renal medications.","supporting_eids":["DX#000002","DX#000004","DX#000009","DX#000010","PX#000002","LAB#000018","LAB#000021","LAB#000023","LAB#000048","LAB#000051","LAB#000055","LAB#000063","LAB#000065","LAB#000067","LAB#000077","LAB#000081","LAB#000084","LAB#000085","LAB#000087","LAB#000091","LAB#000093","LAB#000095","LAB#000126","LAB#000129","LAB#000130","LAB#000132","LAB#000145","LAB#000147","LAB#000149","LAB#000150","LAB#000153","LAB#000155","LAB#000157","PHARM#000021","PHARM#000022","PHARM#000023","PHARM#000027","PHARM#000032","PHARM#000042","PHARM#000045","PHARM#000046","PHARM#000047","PHARM#000053","PHARM#000056","PHARM#000057","RX#000011","RX#000021","RX#000026","RX#000027","RX#000029","RX#000030","RX#000044","RX#000047","RX#000049","RX#000057","RX#000058","RX#000060","RX#000061","DS#000001"]},{"problem":"Atrial fibrillation","status_at_discharge":"She has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and was on aspirin at baseline. During this admission she had at least one brief episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response that self-terminated; she remained hemodynamically stable and largely asymptomatic. Rate-control agents were not continued long term, and systemic anticoagulation was not initiated, given her low stroke risk and concerns about bleeding and adherence. She was maintained on aspirin 325 mg daily. At discharge she was in sinus rhythm and clinically stable.","supporting_eids":["DX#000006","PHARM#000025","RX#000009","DS#000001"]},{"problem":"Advanced HIV/AIDS on HAART with opportunistic infection prophylaxis","status_at_discharge":"She has advanced AIDS with a recent CD4 count in the low teens and high viral load prior to restarting HAART. Two weeks before admission she had restarted a regimen of abacavir 600 mg daily, atazanavir 300 mg daily, ritonavir 100 mg daily, and emtricitabine 200 mg twice weekly, which was continued throughout hospitalization. She also received Pneumocystis prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg weekly. CSF HIV viral load was sent as part of the LP workup. At discharge she remained clinically stable on HAART and prophylaxis, with outpatient HIV follow-up arranged.","supporting_eids":["DX#000001","PHARM#000007","PHARM#000008","PHARM#000009","PHARM#000010","PHARM#000015","RX#000008","RX#000010","RX#000013","RX#000051","RX#000036","MICRO#000018","DS#000001"]},{"problem":"Pancytopenia with macrocytosis","status_at_discharge":"Throughout the admission she had leukopenia (WBC ~2.5–3.6 K/uL), macrocytic anemia (hemoglobin ~10.1–12.2 g/dL, MCV 103–105 fL), and thrombocytopenia (platelets ~102–130 K/uL). RDW was mildly elevated. Coagulation parameters (PT, INR, PTT) were normal, and there were no bleeding events or transfusions. The cytopenias were attributed to HIV-related bone marrow suppression and chronic disease. At discharge her counts remained low but stable, and she was clinically well.","supporting_eids":["LAB#000001","LAB#000003","LAB#000004","LAB#000006","LAB#000008","LAB#000011","LAB#000012","LAB#000013","LAB#000014","LAB#000024","LAB#000025","LAB#000026","LAB#000036","LAB#000037","LAB#000038","LAB#000040","LAB#000041","LAB#000042","LAB#000043","LAB#000044","LAB#000068","LAB#000069","LAB#000070","LAB#000072","LAB#000073","LAB#000074","LAB#000075","LAB#000076","LAB#000096","LAB#000097","LAB#000098","LAB#000100","LAB#000101","LAB#000102","LAB#000103","LAB#000104","LAB#000113","LAB#000114","LAB#000115","LAB#000117","LAB#000118","LAB#000119","LAB#000120","LAB#000121","LAB#000133","LAB#000134","LAB#000135","LAB#000137","LAB#000138","LAB#000139","LAB#000140","LAB#000141","LAB#000158","LAB#000159","LAB#000160","LAB#000162","LAB#000163","LAB#000164","LAB#000165","LAB#000166","DS#000001"]}],"relative_discharge_time":"H+97:13","treatments_and_meds":[{"details":"Given her history of V1 zoster with ophthalmic involvement and new right facial ulcerative lesions with increased pain and headache, she was started on systemic acyclovir (initially oral, then IV) and topical acyclovir ointment, along with acyclovir eye ointment per Ophthalmology. After Dermatology biopsies and virologic studies from skin scrapings and tissue were negative for HSV and VZV, and pathology favored eosinophilic hypersensitivity/folliculitis, acyclovir was discontinued in consultation with Infectious Disease and Dermatology.","supporting_eids":["DX#000003","DX#000008","PHARM#000003","PHARM#000004","PHARM#000005","PHARM#000024","PHARM#000026","RX#000004","RX#000005","RX#000007","RX#000023","RX#000032","MICRO#000001","MICRO#000002","MICRO#000003","MICRO#000004","MICRO#000005","MICRO#000006","MICRO#000007","MICRO#000008","MICRO#000011","DS#000001"],"treatment_or_med":"Empiric antiviral therapy for suspected zoster"},{"details":"Dermatology performed punch biopsies of the left arm and right face, which showed eosinophilic hypersensitivity reaction with follicular accentuation and negative HSV/VZV, PAS-D, and Gram stains. Tissue culture grew only coagulase-negative staph. Based on these findings, the rash was managed as eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis with hydroxyzine for pruritus and topical mupirocin cream 2% twice daily to facial lesions. Systemic cephalexin, initially considered for impetigo, was not continued. By discharge, facial ulcerations and chronic prurigo lesions were healing and pruritus was improved.","supporting_eids":["PX#000001","DX#000005","DX#000008","MICRO#000009","MICRO#000010","MICRO#000011","MICRO#000012","MICRO#000013","MICRO#000014","PHARM#000016","PHARM#000036","RX#000016","RX#000042","PHARM#000020","RX#000019","DS#000001"],"treatment_or_med":"Dermatologic management of eosinophilic dermatitis/folliculitis"},{"details":"Because of worsening chronic headaches with photophobia in the setting of advanced HIV, she underwent CT head, MRI brain without contrast, and a fluoroscopic-guided lumbar puncture. CT and MRI showed no infarct, hemorrhage, mass, or abnormal parenchymal signal. LP yielded clear CSF with normal cell counts, protein, and glucose, negative cryptococcal antigen, and negative bacterial, fungal, viral, and AFB cultures. These results ruled out CNS infection or mass lesion, and headaches were managed symptomatically with oxycodone and later acetaminophen–caffeine–butalbital.","supporting_eids":["DX#000007","DX#000001","RAD#000002","RAD#000003","RAD#000004","PX#000003","LAB#000105","LAB#000106","LAB#000107","LAB#000108","LAB#000109","LAB#000110","LAB#000111","LAB#000112","MICRO#000015","MICRO#000016","MICRO#000017","MICRO#000019","MICRO#000020","MICRO#000021","PHARM#000035","PHARM#000049","RX#000037","RX#000053","DS#000001"],"treatment_or_med":"Evaluation of headache with neuroimaging and lumbar puncture"},{"details":"She continued thrice-weekly hemodialysis during the admission. Chronic ESRD medications were optimized: sevelamer carbonate dose was increased to 1600 mg TID with meals, cinacalcet 60 mg daily was continued, and she received IV doxercalciferol and epoetin with dialysis, along with heparin for circuit anticoagulation and heparin dwell for catheter locks.","supporting_eids":["DX#000002","DX#000004","DX#000009","DX#000010","PX#000002","LAB#000048","LAB#000051","LAB#000055","LAB#000063","LAB#000065","LAB#000067","LAB#000077","LAB#000081","LAB#000084","LAB#000085","LAB#000087","LAB#000091","LAB#000093","LAB#000095","LAB#000126","LAB#000129","LAB#000130","LAB#000132","LAB#000145","LAB#000147","LAB#000149","LAB#000150","LAB#000153","LAB#000155","LAB#000157","PHARM#000021","PHARM#000022","PHARM#000023","PHARM#000027","PHARM#000032","PHARM#000042","PHARM#000045","PHARM#000046","PHARM#000047","PHARM#000053","PHARM#000056","PHARM#000057","RX#000011","RX#000021","RX#000026","RX#000027","RX#000029","RX#000030","RX#000044","RX#000047","RX#000049","RX#000057","RX#000058","RX#000060","RX#000061","DS#000001"],"treatment_or_med":"Hemodialysis and ESRD management"},{"details":"She had restarted HAART two weeks prior to admission with abacavir 600 mg daily, atazanavir 300 mg daily, ritonavir 100 mg daily, and emtricitabine 200 mg twice weekly; this regimen was continued throughout hospitalization. Given her advanced immunosuppression, she also received Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with TMP-SMX DS one tablet three times weekly and MAC prophylaxis with azithromycin 1200 mg once weekly. CSF HIV-1 viral load was obtained as part of the LP workup. She was discharged on the same HAART and prophylaxis regimen with outpatient HIV follow-up.","supporting_eids":["DX#000001","PHARM#000007","PHARM#000008","PHARM#000009","PHARM#000010","PHARM#000015","RX#000008","RX#000010","RX#000013","RX#000051","RX#000036","MICRO#000018","DS#000001"],"treatment_or_med":"HIV antiretroviral therapy and opportunistic infection prophylaxis"},{"details":"Her chronic right facial and scalp pain from prior V1 zoster and her headaches were managed with neuropathic and opioid analgesics. Per report, she had an uneventful HD session \ntoday and arrived home without incident. While lying down on the \ncouch she had the sudden onset of weakness, lightheadedness, and \nmild sensation of room spinning. Most prominent symptom was \nweakness; patient was unable to get herself off the couch. She \nbecame nauseous and had one episode of NBNB vomiting. She called \n911 and when EMS arrived they had to have the fire department \nbreak down her door because she was unable to get up to answer \nit. Her last bowel movement was last night and normal, formed. \nNo fevers, chills, night sweats, diarrhea, abdominal pain. No \nchest pain, shortness of breath, cough. Does not make urine. \n \nIn the ED, initial VS were 96.6, 68, 82/64, 12, 15L nrb. Patient \nreceived a 500 cc bolus of NS and zosyn for empiric coverage for \npossible infection. Transfer VS were 98.5 85 132/63 22 99%. \n\nOn arrival to the floor, patient reports a R sided headache, \nwhich is at baseline for her (has had chronic headaches since \nzoster infection). She still feels lightheaded, but she no \nlonger has the sensation of the room spinning. She reports that \nbaseline SBP's are 90's to 80's after dialysis. Of note, patient \nstarted pregabalin for chronic pain two days ago. She says she \ndid not tolerate gabapentin due to balance problems. \n \n \nPast Medical History:\n- HIV/AIDS: dx'd in ___, last CD4 22, VL 300,000 PCP PNA ___ 3, \non Bactrim and azithromycin, off ___\n- ESRD ___ on HD since ___  s/p 3 failed AVF (b/l UE and RLE), \ncurrently with L common femoral vein tunneled catheter\n- Eosinophilia: undergoing work up with Dr. ___ in ID\n- Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation\n- Right V1 herpes zoster ___ complicated by post-herpetic \nneuralgia and decreased vision in the right eye\n- cervical dysplasia\n- fibroids s/p ablation\n- secondary hyperparathyroidism \n \nSocial History:\n___\nFamily History:\nSister- DM, other sister - CVA's in ___\n \nPhysical Exam:\nADMISSION EXAM: \nVS - 98 98 90/48 16 100 RA\nGEN - Chronically ill-appearing, alert, oriented, fatigued but \nno acute distress  \nHEENT - MMM, EOMI with 3 beats of horizontal nystagmus on \nlateral gaze, sclera injected with tearing bilaterally, OP \nclear, R pupil sluggish (patient states this is baseline) but \nreactive to light, L pupil reactive to light  \nNECK - supple, no JVD\nLYMPH - Shoddy anterior cervical and supraclavicular LAD, no \naxillary or femoral LAD  \nPULM - CTAB, no w/r/r\nCV - RRR, S1/S2, no m/r/g\nABD - soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no guarding or \nrebound \nEXT - Feet cold but pulses 1+ and symmetrical, no significant \nedema\nNEURO - R V1 is tender to palpation and R pupil sluggish (s/p \nzoster infection) but CN II-XII otherwise intact. No nuchal \nrigidity. Kernig's and Brudzinsky are negative. A+O x 3, good \nattention, answering questions appropriately. Motor function \ngrossly normal, though limited by R thigh pain, which patient \nstates is chronic. Strength ___ and symmetrical. \nSKIN - Diffuse hyperpigmented lesions with significant \nexcoriation. Symptoms were most likely due to \nLyrica, which was stopped. \n\nACTIVE ISSUES\n1. Lightheadedness & Weakness: Patient's symptoms of weakness, \nlightheadedness, and malaise are most likley secondary to \nstarting Lyrica given she had started the drug two days before \nsymptom onset and had a similar reaction to gabapentin. Patient \nremained afebrile and had no localizing infectious symptoms \nbeyond the one episode of nausea and vomiting at home. On \nadmission, she had several blood pressures below her baseline \nSBP of 80's-90's, which were concerning for an atypical \npresentation of sepsis in this severely immunocompromised \npatient.  She was started on Vancomycin and Zosyn. Blood \npressures improved with 1.5L IVF. Antibiotics were stopped and \nno further infectious symptoms/signs developed and blood \ncultures were no growth at discharge. Lyrica was stopped on \nadmission and patient was advised not to take it again. \nLightheadedness and weakness were improved at the time of \ndischarge. Orthostatics were negative. \n \n2. Low Health Literacy: Patient demonstrated low health literacy \nsurrounding her HIV and her medications. She was unsure of her \ndaily medications and dosing, so medication reconciliation was \nperformed based on review of OMR and recent chart notes. Patient \nwould likely benefit from meeting with pharmacist for medication \nteaching as an outpatient. \n\n6. Right V1 Post-Herpetic Neuralgia/Headache: Patient continued \nto have pain in her right V1 distribution, which has been \nchronic since a zoster infection in that nerve. She was started on \nlow-dose duloxetine three times a week post-HD after \nconsultation with her outpatient providers. \n\n7. Depressed Mood: No active SI. Seen by ___.
